case_name: M/s Ouchterloney Valley Estates Ltd. & Ors. v. Respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1084-1088 of 1963 are appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 1961 of the Kerala High Court in T.R.C. Nos. 39-42, 31 to 34, 45 and 46, 35 to 38 and 47.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1084-1088 of 1963. Sup./65-8 Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 1961, of the Kerala High Court in T.R.C. Nos. 39- 42, 31 to 34, 45 and 46, 35 to 38 and 47 respectively.

facts.text: The appellants are plantation companies which grow their own tea in tea estates and sell their products.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in these respective appeals are Plantation Companies which grow their own tea in Tea Estates and sell their products.

facts.text: Sales-tax Officers assessed the appellants to sales tax under the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act 11 of 1125 for different years.

anchor.surface_text: Under the relevant provisions of the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act 11 of 1125  hereinafter called the Travancore Act , Sales-tax Officers had assessed the appellants to several amounts of tax in respect of their turn-over for different years.

facts.text: Appellants urged before Sales-tax Officers that transactions were not liable to sales tax, but pleas were rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants had urged before the Sales-tax Officers that the transactions in question were number liable to pay sales-tax, but their pleas were rejected and sales-tax was ordered to be imposed in respect of the said transactions.

facts.text: Sales-Tax Appellate Tribunal concurred with Sales-tax Officers and confirmed assessment orders.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal companycurred with the view taken by the Sales-tax Officers and companyfirmed the respective orders of assessment.

facts.text: Appellants filed revision applications to Kerala High Court under s.15(2) of Travancore Act, which failed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then moved the High Court of Kerala in its revisional jurisdiction under s. 15B of the Travancore Act. These revision applications also failed-.

facts.text: Appellant in appeals Nos. 1084-1088/1963 is Ms Ouchterloney Valley Estates Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: We will accordingly mention the relevant facts in regard to appeals Nos. 1084-1088/1963 in which the appellant is M s Ouchterloney Valley Estates Ltd.

facts.text: Ms Ouchterloney Valley Estates Ltd produces tea in its own tea estates and sells its products but does not carry on buying and selling business itself.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant M s Ouchterloney Valley Estates Ltd. produces tea in its own Tea Estates and sells its products. It does number itself carry on the business of buying and selling its products.

facts.text: Managing Agents of Ms Ouchterloney Valley Estates Ltd are Ms Peirce Leslie Co. Ltd, Coimbatore.

anchor.surface_text: The Managing Agents of the appellant are M s. Peirce Leslie Co. Ltd Coimbatore.

facts.text: Tea produced by appellant sold by public auction at Fort Cochin; purchasers paid at Fort Cochin and obtained delivery orders for godowns at Wellingdon Island.

anchor.surface_text: The quantities of tea produced by the appellant were sold by public auction at Fort Cochin the purchasers paid the companysideration at Fort Cochin and obtained from the auctioneers delivery numberes requesting the godown keepers at Wellingdon Island to deliver the goods.

facts.text: Fort Cochin was in the State of Madras, Wellingdon Island was in the State of Travancore at the relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: Fort Cochin was in the. State of Madras, whereas Wellingdon Island was in the State of Travancore at the relevant time.

facts.text: Assessment periods for appellant: 1952-53, 1953-54, 1954-55, 1955-56, 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: The periods for which assessment has been levied against the appellant are 1952-53, 1953-54, 1954-55, 1955-56 and 1956- 57.

facts.text: Teas produced in estates are graded, weighed, packed in chests, forwarded with garden invoices to godowns of Peirce Leslie Co. Ltd at Wellingdon Island.

anchor.surface_text: Teas produced in the companycerned Estates are graded, weighed and packed in chests in the estates and are subsequently forwarded with garden invoices to the godowns of their Clearing and Forwarding Agents, Messrs. Peirce Leslie Co. Ltd., Cochin, at Welling- don Island to be stored there awaiting further instructions.

facts.text: Brokers in Fort Cochin check weight, draw samples, group chests in lots, publish catalogs, advertise public auction at Fort Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the brokers in Fort Cochin check the weight of the chests, draw samples of their companytents and group the chests in lots. They then publish printed catalogs giving the names of the Estate and the go- downs, the numbers of the lots, the serial numbers and total number of chests in each lot, the weight of each chest and the total weight of each lot and advertise the sale of such chests with export rights, by public auction. at Fort Cochin on particular date and hour.

facts.text: Sale conducted by samples at Fort Cochin, confirmed in name of highest bidder.

anchor.surface_text: The sale is companyducted, by samples, at Fort Cochin, at the proclaimed date and hour and is companyfirmed in the name of the highest bidder.

facts.text: Buyer entitled to open chests, examine contents, submit claims for difference, inferiority, damage by 5pm on 3rd day before prompt day (9th day after sale).

anchor.surface_text: The buyer shall be entitled to open the chests bid by him and examine the companytents thereof to ascertain the actual state and companydition of the tea. Difference or inferiority in quality, description, deterioration, damage and defect in packing will entitle the buyer to submit claims or rejection, or allowance or damage. Such claims must be submitted, after inspection, numberdoubt, number later than 5 P.m. on the 3rd day before the prompt day  ninth day after date of sale  or in the case of removal before the prompt day, at least 24 hours before such removal.

facts.text: Payment to be made in Cochin on or before prompt day (10th day after sale).

anchor.surface_text: Payment shall be made in Cochin on or before prompt day, in cash or by cheque or draft on a Cochin Bank.

facts.text: Delivery to be taken before 5pm on 5th day after prompt day.

anchor.surface_text: Delivery shall be taken before 5 P.m. on the 5th day after prompt day.

facts.text: Kerala High Court in Deputy Commissioner v. A.V. Thomas Co. held property passes at Fort Cochin but sales taxable in Travancore-Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: In that case, the Kerala High Court had proceeded to deal with the matter on the basis that the property in the goods sold passed at Fort Cochin on the fall of the hammer at the auction and that they companyld number be said to be outside sale within the meaning of Art. 286 1   a  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court reversed A.V. Thomas case, holding property passes at Fort Cochin (Madras), so outside sale for Travancore-Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: In that case, this Court has held that the explanation to Art. 286 1  creates a fiction as between two States... the property in teas passed to the buyer under S. 54 of the Act as soon as the offer was accepted on fall of the hammer at Fort Cochin in the State of Madras and, therefore, the only State which companyld have power to levy a tax on such sale would be the State of Madras.

facts.text: Supreme Court held in Malayalam Plantations Ltd. v. Deputy Commissioner that similar tea sales are outside sales for Travancore-Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: The same view has been expressed by this Court in a subsequent decision companying from Kerala in Malayalam Plantations Ltd., Quilon v. The Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales-tax, South Zone, Quilon.

facts.text: Respondent contends sales are inside sales for Kerala as inspection and acceptance occur at Wellingdon Island.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Menon for the respondent State has, however, strenuously companytended that the question as to whether the present sales are outside sales so far as the respondent is companycerned, has never been properly tried... the inspection of the goods took place at these, godowns.

facts.text: Supreme Court heard appeals first on 10th September 1964, adjourned to produce Rules of Tea Trade Association of Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: When those appeals were heard by us first on the 10th September, 1964, the procedure followed in companyducting the sales in question was placed before us... Accordingly, the matter was adjourned to enable the parties to produce the said Rules.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds title to goods passes under s.64(2) Sale of Goods Act on fall of hammer at Fort Cochin auction.

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully companysidered all the rules under which sales in question have been held by public auction, and we are satisfied that title to the goods passed to the buyer under s. 64 2  of the Act as soon as the sale was companypleted by the auctioneer announcing its companypletion by the fall of the hammer.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeals, sets aside Kerala High Court orders, holds sales-tax levy invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeals are allowed, the orders passed by the High Court in revision are set aside, and the levy of sales-tax imposed by the Sale,,-tax authorities against the appellants is held to be invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeals are allowed, the orders passed by the High Court in revision are set aside, and the levy of sales-tax imposed by the Sale,,-tax authorities against the appellants is held to be invalid.

holdings.text: One thing is clear in the present case viz., that the goods in question were not unascertained goods, nor were they non-existing goods; the goods were clearly in existence, they had been graded, weighed and packed in numbered chests and a list was prepared in respect of the contents of these chests separately.

anchor.surface_text: One thing is clear in the present case viz., that the goods in question were not unascertained goods, nor were they non-existing goods were clearly in existence, they had been graded, weighed and packed in numbered chests

holdings.reasoning_summary: Goods pre-existed auction, graded, weighed, packed in specific numbered chests with catalog lists; thus ascertained under SOGA ss.18-19, not unascertained requiring later appropriation.

holdings.text: title to the goods passed to the buyer under s. 64(2) of the Act as soon as the sale was completed by the auctioneer announcing its completion by the fall of the hammer. The initial auction cannot, in our opinion, be treated as an executory contract which became a conditional contract on the fall of the hammer. The auction was an auction sale in respect of ascertained goods and it was completed in every case on the fall of the hammer.

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully considered all the rules under which sales in question have been held by public auction, and we are satisfied that title to the goods passed to the buyer under s. 64 2  of the Act as soon as the sale was completed by the auctioneer announcing its completion by the fall of the hammer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Auction rules (conds.7,11-13,15-16) treat highest bidder as buyer post-hammer, grant inspection/claims/arbitration rights without conditioning title transfer; harmonizes with s.64(2) for completed auction of ascertained goods, rejecting conditional/executory characterization under s.17.

holdings.text: we must hold that the High Court was in error in coming to the conclusion that the Sales-tax authorities were justified in imposing sales-tax against the appellants in regard to the transactions which have given rise to the present appeals.

anchor.surface_text: On that view of the matter, we must hold that the High Court was in error in coming to the conclusion that the Sales-tax authorities were justified in imposing sales-tax against the appellants in regard to the transactions which have given rise to the present appeals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Property passes at Fort Cochin (Madras) under SOGA s.64(2); thus outside sales qua Travancore-Cochin/Kerala per Art.286(1) explanation, as in A.V.Thomas and Malayalam Plantations precedents.

holdings.text: the appeals are allowed, the orders passed by the High Court in revision are set aside, and the levy of sales-tax imposed by the Sales-tax authorities against the appellants is held to be invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeals are allowed, the orders passed by the High Court in revision are set aside, and the levy of sales-tax imposed by the Sale,,-tax authorities against the appellants is held to be invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sales are outside sales for taxing state as situs of sale determined by property transfer location in another state per Art.286; levy unauthorized.

precedents.citation: Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales-tax A. V. Thomas Co, Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales-tax A. V. Thomas Co, Ltd.   In that case, the Kerala High Court had proceeded to deal with the matter on the basis that the property in the goods sold passed at Fort Cochin on the fall of the hammer at the auction and that they companyld number be said to be outside sale within the meaning of Art. 286 1   a  of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales-tax v. A. V. Thomas Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: property in the goods sold passed at Fort Cochin but sales could be taxed by Travancore-Cochin as explanation 2 to s. 2(j) of Travancore Act not violative of Art. 286(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: I.L.R. 1960 Kerala 1395. Meanwhile, the decision of the Kerala High Court in the case of A. V. Thomas Co. 1  was reversed by this Court when the matter came before it in appeal in A. V. Thomas Co. Ltd. v. Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income Tax and Sales Tax, Trivendrum.

precedents.case_name: Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales-tax v. A. V. Thomas Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Kerala High Court decision binding on authorities

precedents.citation: A. V. Thomas Co. Ltd. v. Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income Tax and Sales Tax, Trivendrum

anchor.surface_text: A. V. Thomas Co. Ltd. v. Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income Tax and Sales Tax, Trivendrum.  2  In that case, this Court has held that the explanation to Art. 286 1  creates a fiction as between two States, one where the goods are delivered for companysumption in that State, and the other where the title in the goods passed and the former is treated as the situs of the taxable event to the exclusion of the latter.

precedents.case_name: A. V. Thomas & Co Ltd v Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income Tax and Sales Tax Trivandrum
precedents.cited_proposition: explanation to Art. 286(1) creates fiction; property passes under s.54 Sale of Goods Act on fall of hammer at auction in Madras; outside sale for Travancore-Cochin
precedents.cited_holding: property in teas passed to the buyer under S. 54 of the Act as soon as the offer was accepted on fall of the hammer at Fort Cochin in the State of Madras and, therefore, the only State which companyld have power to levy a tax on such sale would be the State of Madras

anchor.surface_text: McManus v. Fortescue Anr.  2  In that case, the Court of Appeal has held that at a sale by auction subject to a reserve price on the article sold, where the fact that there is a reserve is known, the offer of the auctioneer to sell, the bidding, and the knocking down of the article to the highest bidder are all subject to the companydition that the reserve price should be reached,

precedents.cited_proposition: at auction sale subject to reserve price, fall of hammer does not complete contract if reserve not reached; condition precedent
precedents.cited_holding: the fall of the hammer companyld do away with a companydition expressly stipulated for by the companyditions of sale

anchor.surface_text: 1907 2 K.B. 1. The position in regard to the relevant provisions of the Act bearing on the question as to when title in the goods sold passes, is number in doubt. If the companytract of sale is for ascertained goods which are actually described in the list prepared before the sales are held and it appears that all material particulars about the goods are shown in the list, then the question as to when title passes would depend essentially upon the intention of the parties expressed in the terms of the companytract.

The result is, the appeals are allowed, the orders passed by the High Court in revision are set aside, and the levy of sales-tax imposed by the Sale,,-tax authorities against the appellants is held to be invalid.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals allowed; orders of High Court in revision set aside; levy of sales-tax by sales-tax authorities held invalid
